title: Synthetic Recap
body:
AP SPORTS

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — History arrived not with a roar, but with a relentless, silky-smooth offensive clinic from a 22-year-old prodigy. In a game that will be forever etched in the annals of the Toronto Raptors’ brief existence, Tracy McGrady authored a performance for the ages, single-handedly dismantling the New Jersey Nets with a career-high 45 points in a 97-88 victory.

On a night where his team needed every ounce of his talent, McGrady was simply unguardable. He wasn't just scoring; he was orchestrating a masterpiece, slicing through the Nets' defense with an array of explosive drives and feathery jumpers. His 45-point eruption wasn't merely a high total—it was a statement, a glimpse of the superstar potential that would come to define his Hall of Fame career.

While McGrady’s scoring was the headline, his all-around dominance filled the box score. He contributed 7 rebounds, dished out 5 assists, and anchored the defense with 3 crucial steals and 2 blocked shots, a complete performance that left the home crowd in stunned silence.

The Nets, led by 18 points from Kendall Gill and a double-double of 13 points and 12 rebounds from Jayson Williams, had no answer. They fought valiantly, but how does one counter an unstoppable force? Every time New Jersey threatened to close the gap, McGrady had a response, a bucket that silenced the run and reaffirmed Raptors control.

This was more than a road win; it was the night the NBA world was put on notice. Tracy McGrady had arrived, and in a dazzling 48-minute showcase, he didn't just beat the Nets—he transcended the game, delivering one of the most iconic individual performances in the young franchise's history.
